comments.text: Tons of locals and tourists coming to and from the desert. I wasn't even trying to hitch and got offered a ride in the back of a pickup. Incredibly easy and the desert is a great place to wild camp.

Very easy to hitch across the desert if you don't feel like walking under the heat. Lot's of tourists who are hoping from viewpoint to view point. The desert is also a great place to wild camp, the night sky is apparently breathtaking (it was cloudy when I went unfortunately). Don't forget to pack a lot of water !
Do not try hitchhiking south from this side of the city, had to walk it in the end
A perfect place to go to Cali.

From here you can ask to the police in the checkpoint for a ride, they call it "una cola". I did it and told him that I didn't have money and inmediatly he asked to a van that was passing by. He said yes ans that's it. Local poeple do that. I wasn't asked for money at all.
Another way is to take a moto-taxi to the regional bus station and from there take a bus to Maracaibo. It all cost aorund 200 bolivares instead of 500 bs, that costs the bus form the border.
Mobil gas station

Peaje Ponedera camino a Medellin, muy buen sitio.

Ponedera toll road to Medellin, very good site

Peaje al norte de Medellin, para llegar hay que tomar el Metro de Medellin y bajarse en la ultima estacion llamada NIQUIA. luego tomar un bus hasta el peaje, lo hice en el 2008 con buenos resultados, no me llevaron a mi destino final que era Cartagena pero avance bastante y me dejaron en otro sitio bueno para hacer dedo.

Toll north of Medellin, to get there take the Metro de Medellin and get off at the last station called Niquuia, then take a bus to the toll, I did it in 2008 with good results,
I took a bus to the gas station and from there I asked all the trucks and cars. I waited around 30min and found a truck to San Gil (he was going to Bogota). Nice spot, the staff were nice too
I asked a car on the side of the road. Took me to Calabazo
Take a bus to Puerto Colombia the blue one that says AUTOPISTA. Walk yust after the bridge and there is a spot to stop.

Not the busiest road but busy enough. Lots of cars passing and extremely safe given the military base close by. I was picked up in this area twice, once by an off duty colonel and once by some guys in military uniforms. Incredibly friendly people. They also spoke some English. Highly recommend the town of Nilo as a camping spot as well if you need one. The PD was confused but was more than helpful.
Good spot near a gas station. Lots of cars, right around a corner so people are going slow and have plenty of time to decide to pick you up. Lots of truckers going to Neiva. Lots of mosquitos.

Es una zona donde los camioneros y autos paran para comer e ir al baño, ideal para hacer stop frente a los parqueaderos de los restaurantes, asi tienen donde parar.
Cuando he ido la ruta no era muy movimentada, pero era la única que me llevaba a donde quería llegar, Armenia.
The easiest hitchhiking I've ever done in Colombia. Got picked up in the blink of an eye. Stand at the speed bump and wait for the magic to happen.
Great place to stand if you're heading towards San Agustín or even Popayán (can't give any feedback about that though). You can drop you backpack under the roof of the restaurant if it's raining.
Great spot if you're heading to Gigante. Shade and space for cars to pull over. Stand far enough up the roads so that you can catch the cars coming from La Plata. Got picked up almost instantly.

I was there early in the morning on a Saturday. Everyone there is going to Neiva or Tello (the town before Neiva). Second car that passed stopped. There isn't really any space for cars to pull over but everyone is going slow.

If you can get there, it is a truck-drivers resting area, ideal spot for hitchhiking. They all go to Medellin or to Cartagena in the other way, they drive super slow, you have a lot of space and you can go ask directly to drivers having a break.The exact point is behind "Restaurant La Patrona, Planeta Rica, cordoba" on maps.
Took me 10mn to get a ride to Medellin.
I hitchiked underneath the pedestrian bridge to stand in some shade [Blog Post](http://www.hobospirit.com/hitchhiking-from-cali-to-ipiales/)
got a car to Popayan in 10 min
Salida al sur de Cali. En la vía pasando la Universidad Autonoma, buen punto. También hay una estación de gasolina en la que paran muchos carros.

After the intersection. Cars go slowly and there is a lot of space to pull off. I stood there just thumbing and it took me less than 20 minutes to get a hitch close to Ibagué. Traffic comes from Bogotá, but there is also a lot of local traffic. Maybe I was just really lucky that day.

Detrás del crucero. Traffico desde Bogotá. Consigué un paseo hasta cerca de Ibagué en menos de veinte minutos sin letrero. Sin embargo hay también mucho traffico local. Tal vez sólo tuviese mucha suerte este día.

Walk a little bit away from the Tayrona park entrance and cars will go slow and could take you on your way to the Guajira ask locals where to go as there are many great places around. Hitchhiked here like 5 times never took me more than 15min.
Depending on the season there could be very few cars or a lot. Very east to get a ride to all the good spots near th tayrona park, Guajira and Venezuela.

There is a toll where is pretty easy to get a ride toward Venezuela. It took me less than one hour to get one. If you can get a ride to Riohacha, from there there are buses that charge you 2 or 3 dollars to get to Maicao.

Caminar desde el puente peatonal por la calle, se va encontrando agencias de buses y mas adelante un parqueadero de camiones donde con suerte se puede conseguir fácilmente.
Salimos directo a Tunja.

Take a minibus to Los Patio. Be careful to ask for the end of the town, if not you're ready for 5km walk or to take another bus.
It was easy because I ask a guy stopped who was going there.
I guess asking is the best option !

Road toward Cartagena.There is a toll, we waited one hour. If you are offered for a ride to Sincelejo, be carefull, we got stuck for many hours there. We ended up taking a bus to Toluviejo (2 dollars) and from there we got a ride to Cartagena.
Although I didn't try to get a ride from here, it didn't seem to me a good spot to get a ride. If you walk 2 kmts ahead there is a checkpoint, that was pretty good for me.

Salida de Cartagena, muy cerca al terminal de buses, pasan muchos camiones, furgonetas y buses rumbo a Barranquilla y Santa Marta.

Out of Cartagena, close to the bus terminal, passing many trucks, vans and buses bound for Barranquilla and Santa Marta.
There is a checkpoint, where is easy and safe to get a ride to Barranquilla, at least for me it took me less than half an hour. Cars have place to park.
Low speed and big shoulder.
Direction to Bogota. Jus walk a bit away from crossroad.
A big shoulder on the road, makes  this spot usefull

Peaje Las Palmas camino a Bogota.

Toll Las Palmas, route to Bogota

Muchos estacionamientos de camiones, carretera principal hacia Santa Marta

Many truck parking, main road to Santa Marta

Estación de Servicio (EDS) Plaza Bonita.

Service Station (EDS) Plaza Bonita

Caucasia, hacer dedo frente a la estacion de policia, al frente hay un hotel y restaurantes.

Caucasia, hitchhiking front the police station, in front of a hotel and restaurants

Yarumal, pequeño pueblo en las alturas de Medellin 2300 msnm, buen sitio para descansar, muchos estacionamientos de camiones.

Yarumal, a small village on the heights of 2300 meters Medellin, good place to rest, many truck parking.

Buen sitio para hacer dedo, muchos camiones y en el cruce hay tiendas de comida barata. Rumbo a Cartagena

Good place to hitchhike, many trucks and the crossing of cheap food shops. Sailing to Cartagena
I tried to hitchhike on the road for one hour, no one stop. Then I asked at the gas station and found a car to Socoro quickly

Not many cars passing. Maybe one an hour or so, but all of them picked me up. Was planning to walk to Riosucio but was able to hitch it the way there in about 4 hours. Would have made it in one ride but I got unlucky and my driver had to turn around.
I walked there from the city centre but there's a local bus. Good spot, shade, cars are going slow and there is space for them to pull over. I think most people are heading towards La Plata.

Setup : one guy, not looking obviously foreigner.

Perfect spot to hitchhike, south or north : large road, military control just above so people are driving slow, and you can wait under tree's shadows which is a huge plus on the coast.
Took me 1h to get a ride to Monteria.
I waited for about an hour until a couple took me on a motorcycle to the entrance of Jamundí.
Didnt wait that long but be sure to be picky with your ride. Took me a while because I kept getting rides down the road and there arent many great spots along the way.
Ahi empecé mi camino hasta Armenia, con dos amigas demoramos aproximadamente 12 horas en llegar hasta nuestro destino final.
I began hitchhiking to Cali from here in 2015. It tooke a further two days to reach Cali, read about it on my [blog here](http://www.hobospirit.com/hitchhiking-from-medellin-to-cali/)

Best location for South towards Cali, three petrol stations and room for cars to pull in. Get off the metro at La Estrella continue south and walk up the hill.

La mejor ubicación para el sur hacia Cali, tres estaciones de servicio Consiga del metro en La Estrella continúan sur y pie de la colina .
You wait because it's a long way down - but once you're in you're in! The spot is bad but theres no better one.
A pesar de que es un lugar con espacio para que los autos entren, nadie para, los autos van un poco rápido, y ni miran a los costados.
thank you for your comment, i want to ask you, what kind of vehicle hitch you?
Staff were very friendly in 2014
Terpel gas station with rides to Manizales, Medellín.
Buen lugar para esperar camiones en la ruta a Bogota, hay una estacion de servicio antes de un puente peatonal donde esperar.
I took a bus to Necocli (2.5 dollars) and from there I got a ride to Monteria. I think I was lucky because there were very few cars passing by over there. I waited for 2 hours.
Here is a gas station before the hill, but you can tray about 1-2 km further if you like more quiet spots

Setting: two guys, one Latin looking, the other one obvious foreigner

On our way to Cartagena we had a really lucky shot here. After standing here for about an hour, seeing ourselves already stepping back to the centre of the village where buses are leaving towards north there was suddenly one of this big container trucks stopping for us. The driver assinged us to sit behind the container in the very back. One of the most amazing rides I ever had! The driver told us that in case that the police

This is actually the same as the spot a few kilometres down west at the toll collect station. Someone brought us here in order to only have the vehicles passing by which are definitely going north at the Panamericana Road. It took us (two guys) almost two hours until we almost gave up before someone took us for a two hour ride. Hitchhiking here is feasable but it takes its time.
a lot of local traffic, but after about 40min i got a ride. no probs with police/army.

Centro comercial Exito-Panorama, al frente hay estacionamiento de camiones y un hotel muy economico, aqui tambie se puede tomar el bus hacia el peaje Ponedera al sur de Barranquilla.

Exito-Panorama supermarket, parking is in front of trucks and a very economic hotel, here you can also take the bus to the toll south of Barranquilla Ponedera

Salida norte a Cartagena, no tuve suerte y tomé un bus a Cartagena :(

North exit towards Cartagena, no luck and took a bus to Cartagena :(

You're not protected from the sun and most people are just going to the next town (Villagarzón). The one time I wanted to hitchhike five kilometres down the road a truck going to Ecuador picked me up and when I wanted to hitchhike to Ecuador I had to settle for Villagarzón. Such is life.

Not a great spot, but still useful if you do not want to go inside Monteria. Try waiting just after the roundabout, you have a road that skips the city and bring you on the road 23 to Medellin.
Remember you can also stop motos, you have higher chances to have short moto rides until Planeta Rica !
From there it took me 2 motos and 2 cars in 3 hours to get to Planeta Rica.
just ask for it. / sólo basta levantar la mano..

heard from locals you could hitch boats from this island. stayed for a week, swimming out to boats (cargo, yachts, launches, fish, etc) and didn't get any rides. had to hitch a small launch back to the coast to get to turbo. also sketchy island - before us last 2 people there had been journalists who were murdered (i was told). creepy place, there was a lady locked in her house, and we were told not to walk around too much. stayed with one very nice family in a little hut though. but still creep

Setting: We were two guys going to Cartagena. One guy looked Latin like, another one obvious foreigner.

Now: This is the place where the 2nd peaje (toll collect station) is where all the cars and trucks are passing. Don't try to walk there as it is mentioned in the description of Medellin, it would take you hours! Take a bus from the final metro stop Niquia to there and tell them to drop you off at this place. There is also a Esso gas station just after that. We found it general pretty hard to
Take a ride to puerto Serviez. It's a dirt road, no one use it. I was lucky tu found a truck who pick me up.
Pretty garbage spot. Not many cars passing, but if you arrive late there are plenty of wildcamping spots on the trail next to it and a restaurant nearby.
no ride after three hours in the blazing sun. Read somewhere that this is a good spot. It definitely isn't. Try another one
